questions.promptMd: Which is the best example of a SMART communication objective?
questions.rationaleMd: Checks ability to distinguish vague goals from SMART, outcome-focused objectives.

answers.contentMd: Drive 30% of inactive users to try Feature X within 14 days
answers.feedbackMd: Correct. It is specific, measurable, time‑bound, and action‑oriented.

answers.contentMd: Share updates about Feature X soon
answers.feedbackMd: Vague and not measurable or time‑bound.
Too broad; lacks target, metric, and timeline.
That’s an activity, not an outcome objective.

questions.promptMd: True or False: A good objective focuses on what the sender will do rather than what the audience will do.

answers.feedbackMd: Objectives should target audience knowledge/attitude/behavior, not just sender actions.
Correct. Focus on the audience’s change (KAB), not just activities.

questions.promptMd: Which metric best aligns to the objective: ‘Secure approval to hire 2 FTEs by Friday’?
questions.rationaleMd: Assesses alignment of metrics to decision objectives.

answers.contentMd: Signed approval email/document by Friday EOD
answers.feedbackMd: Yes—direct evidence of the decision by the deadline.

answers.contentMd: Number of stakeholders who read the pre‑read
answers.feedbackMd: Reading is a leading indicator, not the decision outcome.
An activity metric; not tied to the decision.

questions.promptMd: True or False: Mixing multiple primary CTAs in one message can dilute action and should be avoided.

answers.feedbackMd: Correct. One primary CTA focuses attention and improves follow‑through.
Multiple CTAs split attention and reduce completion rates.
